results.name: a(n) = Sum_{k=1..8} floor(A254864(n,k)/A254864(n-1,k)), where A254864(n,k) = n! / (n-floor(n/3^k))!.
comment: A self-similar Sierpinski-type chaotic sequence with rate three at eight levels. [The original name of the sequence.]
A true fractal has an infinite number of levels, but usually only six are visible.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 2..10000
mathematica: p[n_, k_]=n!/Product[i, {i, 1, n-Floor[n/3^k]}] digits=200 f[n_]=Sum[Floor[p[n, k]/p[n-1, k]], {k, 1, 8}] at=Table[f[n], {n, 2, digits}]
program: (define (A088487 n) (add (lambda (k) (floor->exact (/ (A254864bi n k) (A254864bi (- n 1) k)))) 1 8)) ;; Code for A254864bi given in A254864.
;; The following function implements sum_{i=lowlim..uplim} intfun(i)
(define (add intfun lowlim uplim) (let sumloop ((i lowlim) (res 0)) (cond ((> i uplim) res) (else (sumloop (1+ i) (+ res (intfun i)))))))
